para.emphasis: This class is an interface for Optimization algorithms such as CG or steepest descent.

literallayout.computeroutput: 1 #ifndef OptimizationAlgorithm_H_ 2 #define OptimizationAlgorithm_H_ 3 4 #include "../Core/Waveguide.h" 5 6 /** 7 * \class OptimizationAlgorithm 8 * \brief This class is an interface for Optimization algorithms such as CG or 9 * steepest descent. 10 * 11 * The derived classes take residuals and gradients, store them in a history and 12 * compute the next configuration based on the data. This functionality is 13 * encapsulated like this to enable easy exchange and comparison of convergence 14 * rates. Later on the interface will be extended to make use of output 15 * generators during runtime or at the end of the program to directly generate 16 * convergence plots. This class will also be extended to allow for restrained 17 * optimization which will become necessary at some point. \author Pascal Kraft 18 * \date 29.11.2016 19 */ 20 21 template <typename datatype> 22 class OptimizationAlgorithm { 23 public: 24 std::vector<std::vector<datatype>> states; 25 26 std::vector<datatype> residuals; 27 28 OptimizationAlgorithm(); 29 30 ~OptimizationAlgorithm(); 31 32 /** 33 * A function to pass a vector of values, computed by performing a single or 34 * multiple steps with short step-width. "small" in the name references the 35 * fact, that the step width is small. In gerneral this is done whenever an 36 * accurat approximation of a gradient is saught based on linearization. This 37 * computation (especially in finite difference based approaches) can be much 38 * more costly than a big step. In a big step, one forward problem has to be 39 * solved. A small step computation based on finite differences requires 40 * \f$NDofs\f$ forward problems to be solved. This function has the purpose of 41 * passing the result of such computations to the optimization algorithm which 42 * will store it and use it to compute optimization steps in the future. 43 * \param vec This parameter is a vector of changes of the target functional 44 * based on a change in the individual component. The components belonging to 45 * restrained degrees of freedom are set to zero. 46 */ 47 virtual void pass_result_small_step(std::vector<datatype> vec); 48 49 /** 50 * Similar to pass_result_small_step but for the results of big steps. 51 * Since for a big step we always only perform the solution of one forward 52 * problem we also only get one change of the target functional. Therefore in 53 * this case we only pass a value, not a vector of the like. \param input This 54 * is the value describing how much the target functional has changed upon 55 * performing the step last computed by this optimization algorithm. 56 */ 57 virtual void pass_result_big_step(datatype input); 58 59 /** 60 * The optimization is mainly split into two kinds of steps: Full and small 61 * steps. For FD based schemes, a small step is a computation of finite 62 * differences for all degrees of freedom which entails a lot of computation. 63 * Small here refers to the norm of the step width - not necessarily to the 64 * amount of computation required. In general this function is supposed to 65 * gather information about the target functional around the current state. 66 * \param small_steps_before this number tells the scheme how many small steps 67 * were performed before the current request. \return this is true, if the 68 * Optimization Scheme requires more small steps before a big step can be 69 * performed. 70 */ 71 virtual bool perform_small_step_next(int small_steps_before) = 0; 72 73 /** 74 * For the optimization scheme to know, which step size is appropriate, this 75 * function was included. \param small_steps_before similar to 76 * perform_small_step_next this is the number of small steps before the 77 * current one. \return double this is how much the values of the degrees of 78 * freedom should be adapted. 79 */ 80 virtual double get_small_step_step_width(int small_steps_before) = 0; 81 82 /** 83 * This functions returns true, if enough steps were performed to compute the 84 * next state to compute a full solution on. \param small_steps_before number 85 * of small steps performed before this call. \return true, if the next 86 * computation should be a big step - otherwise false. 87 */ 88 virtual bool perform_big_step_next(int small_steps_before) = 0; 89 90 /** 91 * This function computes the states that should be computed next. If the next 92 * step will be a small step the update can be done by simply updating all 93 * dofs with a step width (or only one depending on the pattern) so this 94 * function is only used when a big step will be computed next and therefore 95 * all dofs could change differently. \return This is a vector of degrees of 96 * freedom which can be used by the Optimization Strategy to update the Space 97 * Transformation. 98 * 99 */ 100 virtual std::vector<double> get_big_step_configuration() = 0; 101 102 void WriteStepsOut(std::ofstream &); 103 }; 104 105 #endif
